pageContent: Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 19 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ 1 Introduction 1 The most prevalent argument in the freedom community that we have probably all hear d about over the years goes 2 something like the following: 3 1. There are two of you: 4 1.1. The physical man and woman that was created when you were born. We will call this the “natural being” within 5 this document. 6 1.2. An artificial entity that you represent which is cr eated by the government and therefore subject to government 7 statutes and regulations. This is called the “ straw man ”. 8 2. The straw man is the method by which natural beings “interface” to the commercial world and to the government . 9 Without using the straw m an, you the natural being would be unable to sustain your life because you would be 10 maliciously deprived of the ability to : 11 2.1. Obtain government identification. 12 2.2. Interact commercially with others. 13 3. The government had to create the straw man because it can’t leg islative for the natural being. This is because the 14 natural being is sovereign, and therefore not subject to the law. 15 “Sovereignty itself is, of course, not subject to law, for it is the author and source of law; but in our system, 16 while sovereign power s are delegated to the agencies of government, sovereignty itself remains with the 17 people, by whom and for whom all government exists and acts. And the law is the definition and limitation of 18 power .” 19 [Yick Wo v. Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356 (1886) ] 20 The only thing the government can legislative for or tax are its own creations, so it created the straw man in order to 21 indirectly control, tax, and regulate human beings that would otherwise be beyond their jurisdiction. 22 4. The straw man is represented by your all caps name in combination with a government license number. T he natural 23 being is represented by the Christian lower case name without any government identifying n umber . 24 This pamphlet will use evidence to prove the existence of the “ straw man ”, show how it is created, describe how you can 25 know you are filling its shoes, and describe all the consequences of filling its shoes. We will end the document by directing 26 you at resources that will help you destroy the straw man , force the government to recognize its existence, and suggest 27 ways to function without it. 28 The content of this memorandum is really nothing more than a confirmation of the truths fo und in the followin g document: 29 Why Statutory Civil Law is Law for Government and Not Private Persons , Form #05.037 http://sedm.org/Forms/FormIndex.htm All we are going to prove indirectly is that: 30 1. Nearly all statutory civil law is law for government. 31 2. The only way you can become the subje ct of nearly all statutory civil law is to become an agent, officer, or contractor 32 within the government through the exercise of your right to contract. 33 3. The mechanism by which you become part of the government under the civil law is by signing up for gover nment 34 franchises. All franchises are contracts between the grantor, which is the government, and the grantee, which is you 35 the private person. 36 4. When you become subject to a franchise agreement within the civil law , you enter a partnership between the “res” or 37 “public office” created by your right to contract, and you the private man. That partnership makes you surety for the 38 actions of the officer who runs the entity and makes you a “person” within the meaning of statutory law who is 39 therefore subject to t hat law or franchise . 40 In this treatise, we will not advocate or endorse any of the following misperceptions being taught in the freedom 41 community: 42 1. That birth certificates are used by the government to create a Treasury account they can make withdrawals fro m. 43

Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 20 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ 2. That you have the right to create security interests without consideration using the “straw man” and the Uniform 1 Commercial Code . 2 3. That you can pay your tax bill with bills of exchange or promissory note s. 3 4. That there is any lawful commercial use you can put to the public office that the government creates as a private person 4 not subject to the franchise agreement that created the straw man . 5 All of the above ideas are examined and rebutted in the following document: 6 Policy Document: UCC Redemption , Form # 08.002 http://sedm.org/Forms/FormIndex.htm This is a fascinating subject that we have h eard a lot of people talk about but which very few, in our experience, really 7 understand. Hold on to your seats, because what you are about to read is likely to shatter a lot of misconceptions which 8 have evolved in your mind over the years mainly because of the vacuum of credible information about this subject. 9 2 WHAT is a “straw man”? 10 Black’s Law Dictionary, Sixth Edition , defines the term “straw man” as follow s: 11 Straw man . A “front”; a third party who is put up in name only to take part in a transaction. Nominal party to 12 a transaction; one who acts as an agent for another for the purpose of taking title to real prop erty and 13 executing whatever documents and in struments the principal may direct respecting the property. Person who 14 purchases property, or to accomplish some purpose otherwise not allowed. 15 [Black’s Law Dictionary, Sixth Edition, p. 1421 ] 16 The criteria for the existence of the “straw man” therefore is: 17 1. A commercial transaction involving property . 18 2. Agency of one or more persons on behalf of another person or artificial entity who accomplish es the commercial 19 transaction . 20 3. Property being acquired by a party that otherwise is not allowed or not lawful . 21 An example of a “straw man”, would be the agency created when several companies were contracted privately and 22 individually by Walt Disney to buy t he land used to build Walt Disney World in Florida . Walt d idn’t tell the sellers who 23 the real and final buyer was or what he was doing as a company because if he had used his company’s name, the own ers 24 would have bid up the price or not sold at all and thereby thwarted his plans . Only after he had bought the several pieces of 25 land that he needed through intermediaries did he transfer the titles for all the pieces of land that he had bought collectiv ely 26 into the name of his company. 27 We will now analyze the three elements that form the basis for the existence of the straw man in the following subsections . 28 2.1 Commercial transaction 29 Every commercial transaction you engage in represents an exercise of your r ight to contract. That contract can be ex press, 30 which means in writing , or implied, which means based on your conduct. Below is the definition of the term “ contract ” 31 from the legal dictionary which shows you how implied contracts can be created without y our knowledge or express 32 consent . 33 CONTRACT. A promissory agreement between two or more persons that creates, modifies, or destroys a legal 34 relation. Buffalo Pressed Steel Co. v. Kirwan, 138 Md. 60, 113 A. 628, 630 ; Mexican Petroleum Corporation of 35 Louisiana v. North German Lloyd, D.C.La., 17 F.2d 113,114. 36 An agreement, upon sufficient consideration , to do or not to do a particular thing. 2 Bl.Comm. 442; 2 Kent, 37 Comm. 449. Justice v. Lang, 42 N.Y. 496, 1 Am.Rep. 576; Rabon v. State Finance Corporation, 203 S.C. 183, 38 26 S.E.2d 501, 502 . 39

Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 21 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ An agreement between two or more parties, preliminary Step in making of which is offer by one and 1 acceptance by other , in which minds of parties meet and concur in understanding of terms. Lee v. Travelers’ 2 Ins. Co. of Hartford, Conn., 173 S.C. 185, 175 S.E. 429. 3 A deliberate [e.g. volunta ry] engagement between competent parties, upon a legal consideration, to do, or 4 abstain from doing, some act . Wharton; Smith v. Thornhill, Tex.Com.App. 25 S.W.2d 597, 599. It is agreement 5 creating obligation, in which there must be competent parties, subject- matter, legal consideration, mutuality 6 of agreement, and mutuality of obligation, and agreement must not be so vague or uncertain that terms are 7 not ascertainable. H. Liebes & Co. v. Klengenberg, C. C.A.Ca1.. 23 F.2d 611. 612. A contract or agreement is 8 either where a promise is made on one side and assented to on the other; or where two or more persons enter 9 into engagement with each other by a promise on either side. 2 Steph.Comn1. 54. The writing which contains 10 the agreement of parties, with the terms and conditions, and which serves as a proof of the obligation. 11 [. . .] 12 Constructive Contract 13 Constructive contracts are such as arise when the law prescribes the rights and liabilities of persons who have 14 not in reality entered into a contract at all, but between whom circumstances make it just tha t one should have a 15 right, and the other be subject to a liability, similar to the rights and liabilities in cases of express contract. 16 Donovan v. Kansas City, 352 Mo. 430, 175 S.W.2d 874, 884. 17 [. . .] 18 Quasi Contracts 19 In the civil law. A contractual relation arising out of transactions between the parties which give them mutual 20 rights and obligations, but do not involve a specific and express convention or agreement between them. 21 Keener, Quasi Contr. 1; Elbert County v. Brown, 16 Ga.App. 834, 86 S.E. 651, 665. The lawful and purely 22 voluntary acts of a man, from which there results any obligation whatever to a third person, and sometimes a 23 reciprocal obligation between the parties. Civ. Code La. art. 2293 . 24 Persons who have not contracted with each other are often regarded by the Roman law, under a certain state of 25 facts, as if they had actually concluded a convention between themselves. The legal relation which then takes 26 place between these persons, which has always a similarity to a contract obligation, is therefore termed 27 "obligatio quasi ex contractu." Such a relation arises from the conducting of affairs without authority. 28 (negotiorum gestio,) from the payment of what was n ot due, (solutio indebiti,) from tutorship and curatorship, 29 and from taking possession of an inheritance. Mackeld.Rom.Law 5 491. 30 Legal fiction invented by common law courts to permit recover y by contractual remedy of assumpsit in cases 31 where, in fact, there is no contract, but where circumstances are such that justice warrants a recovery as 32 though there had been a promise. Clark v. Peoples Savings and Loan Ass’n of De Kalb County, 221 Ind. 168, 33 46 N.E.2d 681, 682, 144 A.L.R. 1495. It is not based on intention or consent of the parties, but is founded on 34 considerations of justice and equity, and on doctrine of unjust enrichment. Bruggeman v. Independent School 35 Dist., No. 4, Union Tp., Mitchell County, 227 Iowa 661, 289 N.W. 5, 8, 11. 36 It is not in fact a contract, but an obligation which the law creates in absence of any agreement, when and 37 because the acts of the parties or others have placed in the possession of one person money, or its equivalent, 38 under such circumstances that i n eq uity and good conscience he ought not to retain it. Grossbier v. 39 Chicago, St. P., M. & 0. Ry. Co.. 173 Wis. 503. 181 N.W. 746, 748: It is an implication of law. First Nat. Bank 40 v. Matlock, 99 Okl. 150. 226 P. 328, 331, 36 A.L.R. 1088; Caldwell v. Missouri State Life Ins. Co., 148 Ark. 41 474, 230 S.W. 566, 568. It is what was formerly known as the contract Implied in law; it has no reference to the 42 Intentions or expressions of the parties. The obligation is imposed despite, and frequently in frustra tion of their 43 intention. Town of Balkan v. Village of Buhl, 158 Minn. 271, 197 N.W. 266, 35 A.L.R. 470. 44 [. . .] 45 Express and Implied 46 An express contract is an actual agreement of the parties, the terms of which are openly uttered or declared at 47 the time of making it, being stated in distinct and explicit language, either orally or in writing. 2 Bl.Comm. 443 ; 48 2 Kent, Comm. 450; Linn v. Ross, 10 Ohio 414, 36 Am.Dec. 95; A. J. Yawger & Co. v. Joseph, 184 Ind. 228, 49 108 N.E. 774, 775; In re Pierce, Butler & Pierce Mfg. Co., D.C.N.Y., 231 F. 312, 318 . 50 An implied contract is one not created o r evidenced by the explicit agreement of the parties, but inferred by 51 the law, as a matter of reason and justice from their acts or conduct, the circumstances surrounding the 52 transaction making it a reasonable, or even a necessary, assumption that a contra ct existed between them by 53 tacit understanding . Miller’s Appeal, 100 Pa. 568, 45 Am.Rep. 394; Landon v. Kansas City Gas Co., 54

Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 22 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ C.C.A.Kan., 10 F.2d 263, 266; Caldwell v. Missouri State Life Ins. Co., 230 S.W. 566, 568, 148 Ark. 474; 1 Cameron, to Use of Cameron v. Eynon, 332 Pa. 529, 3 A.2d 423, 424; American La France Fire Engine Co., to 2 Use of American La France & Foamite Industries, v. Borough of Shenandoah, C.C.A.Pa., 115 F.2d 886, 867. 3 Implied contracts are sometimes subdivided into those "implied in fact" and those "implied in law," the 4 former being covered by the definition just given, while the latter are obligations imposed upon a person by 5 the law, not in pursuance of his intention and agreement, either expressed or implied, but even against his 6 will and design, because the circumstances between the parties are such as to render it just that the me 7 should have a right, and the other a corresponding liability, similar to those which would arise from a 8 contract between the. This kind of obligation therefore rests on the principle that whatsoever it is certain a 9 man ought to do that the law will suppose him to have promised to do. And hence it is s aid that, while the 10 liability of a party to an express contract arises directly from the contract, it is just the reverse in the case of a 11 contract "implied in law," the contract there being Implied or arising from the liability. Bliss v. Hoy , 70 Vt. 12 534, 41 A. 1026; Kellum v. Browning's Adm'r. 231 Ky. 308. 21 S.W.2d 459, 465. But obligations of this kind are 13 not properly contracts at all, and should not be so denom inated. There can be no true contract without a 14 mutual and concurrent intention of the parties. Such obligations are more properly described as "quasi 15 contracts." Un ion Life Ins. Co. v. Glasscock, 270 Ky. 750, 110 S.W.2d 681, 686, 114 A. L. R. 373. 16 [Black’s Law Dictionary, Fourth Edition, p. 395 ] 17 The elements required to establish a binding and legally enforceable contract are: 18 1. An offer. 19 2. Mutual consideration. 20 3. Mutual voluntary consent. 21 4. The absence of any duress upon either party. 22 5. Mutual assent or understanding of every aspect of the agreement and all the ramifications o f the property being 23 exchanged. 24 Any transaction which does not contain all of the above elements is voidable but not void. A legal proceeding would 25 usually be necessary to void the transaction if the other party is unwilling to undo the unsatisfactory tra nsaction voluntarily. 26 For instance, here is what the American J urisprudence Legal Encyclopedia, Second Edition says ha ppens to such a 27 transaction if duress is present: 28 “An agreement [consensual contract] obtained by duress, coercion, or intimidation is invalid, since the party 29 coerced is not exercising his free will, and the test is not so much the means by which the party is compelled to 30 execute the agreement as the state of mind induced. 1 Duress, like fraud, rarely becomes material, except where 31 a contract or conveyance has been made which the maker wishes to avoid. As a general rule, duress renders 32 the contract or co nveyance voidable, not void, at the option of the person coerced, 2 and it is susceptible of 33 ratification. Like other voidable contracts, it is valid until it is avoided by the person entitled to avoid it. 3 34 However, duress in the form of physical compu lsion, in which a party is caused to appear to assent when he has 35 no intention of doing so, is generally deemed to render the resulting purported contract void. 4 ” 36 [American Jurisprudence 2d, Duress, Section 21 ] 37 Examples of voidable contracts that do not contain all the above elements include: 38 1. The contract has does not have the signature of BOTH parties . Most government applications only have the signature 39 of the submitter and not the government, for instance. 40 2. Either party to the contract had no authority or delegated authority to bind the party they were representing. For 41 instance, no one in the government other than the legislative branch can obligate the government to do anything. A 42 contract with the government would be invalid and unenforceable if someone in the e xecutive branch signed or 43 represented his or her consent to the contract. 44   1 Brown v. Pierce, 74 U.S. 205, 7 Wall 205, 19 L.Ed. 134 2 Barnette v. Wells Fargo Nevada Nat’l Bank, 270 U.S. 438, 70 L.Ed 669, 46 S.Ct. 326 (holding that acts induced by duress which operate solely on the mind, and fall short of actual physical compulsion, are not void at law, bu t are voidable only, at the election of him whose acts were induced by it); Faske v. Gershman, 30 Misc 2d 442, 215 NYS2d 144; Glenney v. Crane (Tex Civ App Houston (1st Dist)) 352 S.W.2d. 773, writ ref n r e (May 16, 1962); Carroll v. Fetty, 121 W.Va 215, 2 S.E.2d 521, cert den 308 U.S. 571, 84 L.Ed 479, 60 S Ct 85. 3 Faske v. Gershman, 30 Misc 2d 442, 215 NYS2d 144; Heider v. Unicume , 142 Or 416, 20P.2d. 384 ; Glenney v. Crane (Tex Civ App Houston (1st Dist)) 352 S.W.2d. 773, writ ref n r e (May 16, 1962) 4 Restatement 2d, Contracts § 174, stating that if conduct that appears to be a manifestation of assent by a party who does not intend to engage in that conduct is physically compelled by duress, the conduct is not effective as a manifestation of assent.

Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 23 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ “Every man is supposed to know the law. A party who make s a contract with an officer [of the government] 1 without having it reduced to writing is knowingly accessory to a violation of duty on his part. Such a party 2 aids in the violation of the law. " 3 [Clark v. United States, 95 U.S. 539 (1877) ] 4 3. There was no mutual assent or understanding of the terms of the contract or franchise. For instance: 5 3.1. The terms on the government form or contract were not defined wi thin anything that constitutes evidence. The 6 entire Internal Revenue Code, for instance, is “prima facie evidence” according to 1 U.S.C. §204 . Consequently, 7 it is nothing more than a “presumption”. Presum ptions are NOT evidence, it is a violation of due process of law 8 to treat them as evidence, and judges have no delegated authority to turn them into evidence. If a judge turns a 9 presumption into evidence, he is, in fact, establishing a state sponsored rel igion in violation of the First 10 Amendment establishment clause: 11 presumption . An inference in favor of a particular fact. [. . .] 12 A presumption is an assumption of fact that the law requires to be made from another fact or group of facts 13 found or otherwis e established in the action. A presumption is not evidence. A presumption is either 14 conclusive or rebuttable. Every rebuttable presumption is either (a) a presumption affecting the burden of 15 producing evidence or (b) a presumption affecting the burden of proof. Calif.Evid.Code, §600. 16 [Black’s Law Dictionary, Sixth Edition, p . 1185 ] 17 __________________________________________________________________________________________ 18 This court has never treated a presumption as any form of evidence. See, e.g., A.C. Aukerman Co. v. R.L. 19 Chaides Constr. Co., 960 F.2d 1020, 1037 (Fed.Cir.1992) (“[A] presumption is not evidence.”); see also Del 20 Vecchio v. Bowers, 296 U.S. 280, 286, 56 S.Ct. 190, 193, 80 L.Ed. 229 (1935) (“[A presumption] cannot 21 acquire the attribute of evidence in the claimant's favor.”); New York Life Ins. Co. v. Gamer, 303 U.S. 161, 171, 22 58 S.Ct. 500, 503, 82 L.Ed. 726 (1938) (“[A] presumption is not evidence and may not be given weight as 23 evidence.”). Although a decision of this court, Jensen v. Brown, 19 F.3d 1413, 1415 (Fed.Cir.1994) , dealing 24 with presumptions in VA law is cited for the contrary proposition, the Jensen court did not so decide. 25 [Routen v. West, 142 F.3d 1434 C.A.Fed.,1998 ] 26 For further details on this SCAM, see: 27 3.1.1. Presumption: Chief Weapon for Unlawfully Enlarging Federal Jurisdiction , Form #05.017 28 http://sedm.org/Forms/FormIndex.htm 29 3.1.2. Reasonable Belief About Income Tax Liability , Form #05.007 30 http://sedm.org/Forms/FormIndex.htm 31 3.2. The definitions provided were untrustworthy. 32 "IRS Publications, issued by the National Office, explain the law in plain language for taxpayers and their 33 advisors... While a good source of general information, publications should not be cited to sustain a position ." 34 [ Internal Rev enue Manual, Section 4.10.7.2.8 (05 -14- 1999)] 35 3.3. One or both parties defined the terms that were not defined and those definitions conflict with the definitions 36 understood by the other party. For instance, the following form on our website defines many of the terms on 37 government tax forms to be the OPPOSITE of what the code says, and thereby invalidates the enforceability of 38 the “trade or business” f ranchise/contract that is the heart of the income tax: 39 Tax Form Attachment , Form #04.201 http://sedm.org/Forms/Form Index.htm 4. Your right to receive the “consideration” connected with the contract is not enforceable in court. In other words, you 40 have been deprived of a remedy for deprivation of consideration in a real, constitutional court and NOT a legislative 41 “franc hise court” such U.S. Tax Court. See: 42 The Tax Court Scam , Form #05.039 http://sedm.org/Forms/FormIndex.htm 5. The thi ng promised may be withdrawn at any time by the legal person who made the promise as a condition of the 43 contract. 44 “... railroad benefits, like social security benefits, are not contractual and may be altered or even eliminated at 45 any time.” 46 [United States R ailroad Retirement Board v. Fritz , 449 U.S. 166 (1980) ] 47 _____________________________________________________________________________________ 48

Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 24 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ “We must conclude that a person covered by the Act has not such a right in benefit payments ... This is not t o 1 say, however, that Congress may exercise its power to modify the statutory scheme free of all constitutional 2 restraint.” 3 [Flemming v. Nestor , 363 U.S. 603 (1960) ] 4 _____________________________________________________________________________________ 5 "What, then, is meant by the doctrine that contracts ar e made with reference to the taxing power resident in the 6 State, and in subordination to it? Is it meant that when a person lends money to a State, or to a municipal 7 division of the State having the power of taxation, there is in the contract a tacit reser vation of a right in the 8 debtor to raise contributions out of the money promised to be paid before payment? That cannot be, because if 9 it could, the contract (in the language of Alexander Hamilton) would 'involve two contradictory things: an 10 obligation to do, and a right not to do; an obligation to pay a certain sum, and a right to retain it in the shape 11 of a tax. It is against the rules, both of law and of reason, to admit by implication in the construction of a 12 contract a principle which goes in destruction of it.' The truth is, States and cities, when they borrow money 13 and contract to repay it with interest, are not acting as sovereignties . They come down to the level of ordinary 14 individuals. Their contracts have the same meaning as that of similar contra cts between private persons. 15 Hence, instead of there being in the undertaking of a State or city to pay, a reservation of a sovereign right to 16 withhold payment, the contract should be regarded as an assurance that such a right will not be exercised. A 17 prom ise to pay, with a reserved right to deny or change the effect of the promise, is an absurdity." 18 [Murray v. City of Charleston, 96 U.S. 432 (1877) ] 19 Likewise, any transaction that does not involve REAL consideration is also voidable. An example of a voidable contract is 20 one in which the transaction was between one or more private persons and the alleged consideration involves Federal 21 Reser ve Notes . Federal Reserve Notes do NOT constitute legitimate consideration because: 22 1. Federal Reserve Notes are lawful money ONLY for PUBLIC debts, not private debts. 23 2. Federal Reserve Notes are nowhere defined in the law as a species of “dollar”, nor are they THE dollar mentioned in 24 the constitution. See: 25 SEDM Exhibit #06 . 007 http://sedm.org/Exhibits/ExhibitIndex.htm 3. Federal Reserve Notes are not redeemable from the government for anything of value. Redeemability ended in 1972. 26 Beyond that point, there is no real consideration involved in the transaction and our money system becomes nothing 27 but a big counterfeiting franchise where the government has a monopoly on counterfeiting. 28 4. Federal Reserve Notes are legally defined as promissory notes, and the definition of “money” in Black’s Law 29 Dictionary EXCLUDES “notes”: 30 Money : In usual and ordinary acceptation it means coins and paper currency used as circulating medium of 31 exchange, and does not embrace notes , bonds, evidences of debt, or other personal or real 32 estate. Lane v. Railey, 280 Ky. 319, 133 S.W.2d 74, 79, 81. 33 [Black’s Law Dictionary, Sixth Edition, p. 1005 ] 34 If you would like to know more about the above SCAM , see: 35 The Money Scam , Form #05.041 http://sedm.org/Forms/FormIndex.htm One little known act which most people don’t consid er to be a contract but which in fact is would be the act of forming a 36 corporation. The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that such an act constitutes a contract between the stockholders and the 37 government : 38 The court held that the first company's charter was a contract between it and the state, within the protection of 39 the constitution of the United States, and that the charter to the last company was therefore null and void., Mr. 40 Justice DAVIS, delivering the opinion of the court, said that, if anything was settled by an unbroken chain of 41 decisions in the federal courts, it was that an act of incorporation was a contract between the state and the 42 stockholders, 'a departure from which now would involve dangers to society that cannot be foreseen, whould 43 shock the sense of justice of the country, unhinge its business interests, and weaken, if not destroy, that 44 respect which has always been felt for the judicial department of the government.' 45 [New Orleans Gas Co. v. Louisiana Light Co., 115 U.S. 650 (1885) ] 46 This document will focus almost exclusively on implied, constructive, or quasi contracts, because they are the me chanism 47 by which both the straw man is created and by which you become the surety for the straw man. Examples of implied or 48 “quasi contracts” are income taxes: 49

Proof that There Is a “Straw man” 25 of 184 Copyright Sovereignty Education and Defense Ministry , http://sedm.org Form 05.042, Rev. 12- 26- 200 8 EXHIBIT:________ “Even if the judgment is deemed to be colored by the nature of the obligation whose validity it establishes, and 1 we are free to re- examine it, and, if we find it to be based on an obligation penal in character, to refuse to 2 enforce it outside the state where rendered, see Wisconsin v. Pelican Insurance Co., 127 U.S. 265 , 292, et seq. 3 8 S.Ct. 1370, compare Fauntleroy v. Lum, 210 U.S. 230 , 28 S.Ct. 641, still the obligation to 4 pay taxes is not penal. It is a statutory liability, quasi 5 contractual in nature, enforceable, if there is no exclusive 6 statutory remedy, in the civil courts by the common -law action 7 of debt or indebitatus assumpsit. United States v. Chamberlin, 219 U.S. 250 , 31 S.Ct. 8 155; Price v. United States, 269 U.S. 492 , 46 S.Ct. 180 ; Dollar Savings Bank v. United States, 19 Wall. 227 ; 9 and see Stockwell v. United States, 13 Wall. 531, 542 ; Meredith v. United States, 13 Pet. 486, 493 . This was 10 the rule established in the English courts before the Declaration of Independence. Attorney General v. Weeks, 11 Bunbury's Exch. Rep. 223; Attorney General v. Jewers and Batty, Bunbury's Exch. Rep. 225; Attorney General 12 v. Hatton, Bunbury's Exch. Rep. [296 U.S. 268, 272] 262; Attorney General v. _ _, 2 Ans.Rep. 558; see 13 Comyn's Digest (Title 'Dett,' A, 9); 1 Chitty on Pleading, 123; cf. Attorney General v. Sewell, 4 M.&W. 77. “ 14 [Milwaukee v. White, 296 U.S. 268 (1935) ] 15 Below is the meaning of “quasi -contract” from the above quote: 16 " Quasi contact . An obligation which law creates in absence of agreement; it is invoked by courts where there 17 is unjust enrichment. Andrews v. O’Grady, 44 Misc.2d 28, 252 N.Y.S.2d 814, 817. Sometimes referred to as 18 implied -in-law contracts (as a legal fiction) to distinguish them from implied -in-fact contracts (voluntary 19 agreements inferred from the parties' conduct). Function of "quasi -contract" is to raise obligation in law where 20 in fact the parties made no promise, and it is not based on apparent intention of the parties. Fink v. Goodson - 21 Todman Enterprises, Limited, 9 C.A.3d 996, 88 Cal.Rptr. 679, 690. See also Contract." 22 [Black’s Law Dictionary, Sixth Edition, p. 1245 ] 23 2.2 Agency 24 The U.S. Supreme Court has admitted that ALL the powers of the government are exercised through individual agency and 25 private contracts and by NO other method: 26 “All the powers of the government must be carried into operation by individual agency, either through the 27 medium of public officers, or contracts made with individuals. ” 28 [Osborn v. Bank of U.S., 22 U.S. 738 (1824) ] 29 Agency is legally defined as follows: 30 AGENCY. Includes every relation in which one person acts for or represents another by latter's authority , 31 Saums v. Parfet, 270 Mich. 165, 258 N.W. 235, where one person acts for another, either in the relationship of 32 principal and agent, master and servant, or employer or proprietor and independent contractor, Gorton v. 33 Doty, 57 Idaho 792, 69 P.2d 136,139 . 34 Properly speaking, agency relates to commercial or business transactions. Humble Oil & Re. fining Co. v. 35 Bell, Tex.Civ.App., 172 S.W.2d 800, 803, and frequently is used in connection with an arrangement which 36 does no t in law amount to an agency , as where the essence of an arrangement is bailment or sale, as in the 37 case of a sale agency exclusive in certain territory. State Compensation Ins. Fund v. Industrial Accident 38 Commission, 216 Cal. 351, 14 P.2d 306, 310. 39 It also designates a place at which business of company or individual is transacted by an agent. Johnson 40 Freight Lines v. Until 1905 the overwhelming weight of authority was to the effect that, if the 4 petitioning party was domiciled in good faith in any state, that state could render a divorce decree on 5 constructive service valid not only in the state of its rendition, but which would be recognized everywhere. In 6 Atherton v. Atherton, 181 U.S. 155, 21 S.Ct. 544, 45 L.Ed. 794, the United States Supreme Court apparently 7 recognized that doctrine. In that case the parties were living together and domiciled in Kentucky. That state was 8 the last state where the parties lived together as husband and wife. She brought an action for divorce in New York, her husband defending 10 on the ground that he had secured a divorce in Kentucky on constructive service. New York refused to recognize 11 the validity of the Kentucky decree, on the ground that Kentucky could not in such an action affect the status of 12 a citizen of New York. The United States Supreme Court reversed the New York decisions ( 82 Hun, 179, 31 N. 13 Y. S. 977; Id. 155 N. Y. 129, 49 N. E. 933, 40 L. R. A. 291, 63 Am. St. Rep. 650) and *33 held that the Kentucky 14 decree was entitled to full faith and credit even though the wife was not served with process and not appear in 15 the Kentucky action, and even though at the time the decree was rendered the wife was a resident of and 16 domiciled in New York. In so holding, however, the court pointed out that the reason the Kentucky decree was 17 entitled to full faith and cr edit was because Kentucky had jurisdiction over the marriage status by virtue of the 18 fact that that state was the matrimonial domicile, i. e., the last place the parties lived together as husband and 19 wife. Then in 1905, the United States Supreme Court decided the Haddock Case, supra. Here the parties were 20 married and domiciled in the state of New York. The husband, without cause, abandoned his wife and went to 21 and acquired a domicile in Connecticut. Thereafter the husband secured in Connecticut a divorce on 22 constructive service. Several years later the wife sued for divorce in New York, and secured personal service on 23 the husband. The husband set up as a defense the Connecticut decree. New York refused to recognize it. The 24 Supreme Court of the United States held that although the Connecticut decree was probably good in that state, 25 it was without binding force in New York, and was not entitled to full faith and credit. The court pointed out that 26 the matrimonial domicile of the parties was New York, and that in such a case Connecticut had no jurisdiction 27 over the marriage status so as to affect the status of a New York resident. New York could recognize the 28 Connecticut decree, but it could not be compelled to do so under the full faith and credit clause.
